intro: Leucopogon obtusatus, commonly known as the broad-leaved heath, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and small, showy flowers. The plant typically grows in acidic, well-drained soils in forested areas and is often found in sandhill or pine flatwood habitats. Its leaves are broad and leathery, and its flowers are usually pink or white, blooming in late spring to early summer. Leucopogon obtusatus plays an important ecological role in its native habitat by providing food and shelter for various wildlife species.
